title: Chinese embassy donated books and sports equipment to Kamuzu Academy in Malawi
description: On November 21, 2009, the Chinese embassy donated books and sports equipment to Kamuzu Academy in Malawi. The ambassador established a "Chinese Corner" at the library by donating more than 300 volumes of Chinese books as well as basketball and soccer equipment. The value of this donation is unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese embassy donated books and sports equipment to Kamuzu Academy in Malawi

# Description
On November 21, 2009, the Chinese embassy donated books and sports equipment to Kamuzu Academy in Malawi. The ambassador established a "Chinese Corner" at the library by donating more than 300 volumes of Chinese books as well as basketball and soccer equipment. The value of this donation is unknown.
justification: Project is focused on educational and cultural exchange without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of books and sports equipment to educational institution, establishment of cultural corner

title: Chinese embassy donates proceeds from charity sale to Malawi International Women's Association
description: On October 31, 2009, the Chinese embassy donated proceeds from charity sale to the International Women's Association of Malawi (IWAM). title: Chinese government sponsors 23 students to study in China
description: On August 28, 2009, representatives from the Chinese embassy in Malawi met with the 23 recipients of the 2009/10 Chinese Government Scholarship. The scholarship funds the students to study in China and is sponsored by the Chinese government. The students will study in China from September 2009 to June 2010.

title: Hanban provides grant for establishment of Confucius Institute at University of Malaysia
description: On July 8, 2009, Hanban and Beijing Foreign Studies University and University of Malaysia signed an agreement to establish the first Confucius Institute in Malaysia at the University of Malaysia (Universiti Malaya or 马来亚大学) in the city of Kuala Lumpur. The Confucius Institute was officially inaugurated in March 2010. It occupies an area of 1,415 m2. It is a multi-functional venue integrating office, Chinese language teaching, book browsing and Chinese culture exhibition. The Confucius Institute has 8 Chinese government-sponsored professional Chinese teachers and 4 volunteer Chinese teachers and offers various Chinese language courses.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Hanban provides grant for establishment of Confucius Institute at University of Malaysia

# Description
On July 8, 2009, Hanban and Beijing Foreign Studies University and University of Malaysia signed an agreement to establish the first Confucius Institute in Malaysia at the University of Malaysia (Universiti Malaya or 马来亚大学) in the city of Kuala Lumpur. The Confucius Institute was officially inaugurated in March 2010. It occupies an area of 1,415 m2. It is a multi-functional venue integrating office, Chinese language teaching, book browsing and Chinese culture exhibition. The Confucius Institute has 8 Chinese government-sponsored professional Chinese teachers and 4 volunteer Chinese teachers and offers various Chinese language courses.
justification: Project focuses on education and cultural exchange without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Establishment of Confucius Institute, Chinese language teaching, cultural exhibition

title: China Eximbank provides $330 million preferential buyer's credit for Second Penang Bridge Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#34958)
description: In 2006, the Government of Malaysia selected UEM Group Berhad — a wholly owned subsidiary of Khazanah Nasional Bhd — as the concessionaire responsible for building, managing, operating and maintaining the second Penang bridge. Then, on July 13, 2007, a joint venture called the CHEC-UEMC Consortium was formed by China Harbour Engineering Company Ltd (51% ownership stake) and UEMC (49% ownership stake) to implement the Penang Second Crossing Bridge Construction Project. UEMC is a subsidiary of UEM Group. On the same day, China Eximbank and Bank Pembangunan — a state-owned development bank in Malaysia — signed a memorandum of agreement (MOA) regarding a $800 million preferential buyer's credit (PBC) for the Second Penang Bridge Construction Project (captured via Project ID #34958). The specified borrowing terms of the PBC were as follows: 20 year maturity and 3% interest rate. The proceeds of the PBC were to be used by the borrower to partially finance an EPC contract with the CHEC-UEMC Consortium. However, UEM and CHEC could not arrive at a shareholders agreement in July 2008 due to disagreements over the apportionment of jobs and costs. Then, on August 29, 2008, the Malaysian Government terminated its concession agreement with UEM Group Berhad. Jambatan Kedua Sdn Bhd (JKSB) -- a special purpose vehicle and wholly owned company of Malaysia’s Ministry of Finance Incorporated (MOF Inc.) -- was subsequently appointed as the concessionaire responsible for the Second Penang Bridge Construction Project.   In 2009, China Eximbank and JKSB signed a $330 million PBC agreement for the Second Penang Bridge Construction Project. Malaysia’s Ministry of Finance issued a sovereign guarantee in support of the loan (PBC). China Eximbank waived the requirement that the borrower purchase buyer’s credit insurance from Sinosure. The borrower made repayments worth $11 million in 2016 and $22 million in 2017. As of December 31, 2017, the loan’s amount outstanding was $297 million. As of December 31, 2018, the loan’s amount outstanding was approximately $288 million (RM 1.2 billion).   The purpose of the project was to construct a 24 km (15 mi) dual carriageway toll bridge that connects Bandar Cassia (Batu Kawan) in Seberang Perai on mainland Peninsular Malaysia with Batu Maung on Penang Island. The bridge consists of precast segmental concrete marine viaducts in 55-meter (180-feet) span modules and a cast in-situ concrete cable-stayed bridge measuring 475 meters (1,558 feet). It is the second bridge to link the island to the mainland after the first Penang Bridge. It extends over 16.9 km (10.5 mi) of water, making it the longest bridge in Malaysia and the second longest in Southeast Asia.   China Harbour Engineering Company Ltd (CHEC) and UEM Builders were the main contractors responsible for implementation. Construction began on November 8, 2008 and the originally scheduled project completion date was November 8, 2013. As of December 2009, the project had achieved an 8.65% completion rate. It was 24% complete as of April 2010. On January 27, 2011, the construction of the main bridge pile foundation was completed. The project was 60.87% complete as of March 2012. The capping of the main tower took place on August 7, 2012. As of October 3, 2012, the project was 84% complete. The final closure of the cable stayed bridge at the main navigational span of the Penang Second Bridge was completed on April 20, 2013. Then, on April 30, 2013, Prime Minister Najib Tun Razak became the country’s first leader to use the Penang Second Bridge to cross from the island to the mainland to attend a function in Kepala Batas, Seberang Perai. Penang Second Bridge was officially completed and accepted by the project owner (JKSB) on September 15, 2013. It was opened to the traffic at 12.01 AM on March 2, 2014 and renamed the Sultan Abdul Halim Muadzam Shah Bridge. It was named after Tuanku Abdul Halim Muadzam Shah, the Sultan of Kedah and the reigning Yang di-Pertuan Agong of Malaysia, by Prime Minister Datuk Seri Najib Tun Razak.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Second Penang Bridge Project, the E28 Bridge Construction Project, and the Penang Second Crossing Bridge Construction Project. The Chinese project title is 马来西亚槟城二桥工程 or 马来西亚槟城二桥（第二跨海大桥) or 马来西亚槟城二桥项目. The Malay project title is Jambatan Sultan Abdul Halim Muadzam Shah or Jambatan Kedua Pulau Pinang. 2. The China Eximbank loan that supported this project is not included in the Overseas Development Finance Dataset that Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center published in December 2020. 3. The $800 million PBC pledge in 2007 is captured in Project ID#34958. The $330 million PBC commitment in 2009 is captured in Project ID#66615. 4. Malaysia’s Ministry of Finance Incorporated is a corporate entity owned by the Government of Malaysia’s Ministry of Finance that has the authority to enter into contracts, acquisitions, purchases, possessions, holdings and maintains tangible and intangible assets.
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
China Eximbank provides $330 million preferential buyer's credit for Second Penang Bridge Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#34958)

# Description
In 2006, the Government of Malaysia selected UEM Group Berhad — a wholly owned subsidiary of Khazanah Nasional Bhd — as the concessionaire responsible for building, managing, operating and maintaining the second Penang bridge. Then, on July 13, 2007, a joint venture called the CHEC-UEMC Consortium was formed by China Harbour Engineering Company Ltd (51% ownership stake) and UEMC (49% ownership stake) to implement the Penang Second Crossing Bridge Construction Project. UEMC is a subsidiary of UEM Group. On the same day, China Eximbank and Bank Pembangunan — a state-owned development bank in Malaysia — signed a memorandum of agreement (MOA) regarding a $800 million preferential buyer's credit (PBC) for the Second Penang Bridge Construction Project (captured via Project ID #34958). The specified borrowing terms of the PBC were as follows: 20 year maturity and 3% interest rate. The proceeds of the PBC were to be used by the borrower to partially finance an EPC contract with the CHEC-UEMC Consortium. However, UEM and CHEC could not arrive at a shareholders agreement in July 2008 due to disagreements over the apportionment of jobs and costs. Then, on August 29, 2008, the Malaysian Government terminated its concession agreement with UEM Group Berhad. Jambatan Kedua Sdn Bhd (JKSB) -- a special purpose vehicle and wholly owned company of Malaysia’s Ministry of Finance Incorporated (MOF Inc.) -- was subsequently appointed as the concessionaire responsible for the Second Penang Bridge Construction Project.   In 2009, China Eximbank and JKSB signed a $330 million PBC agreement for the Second Penang Bridge Construction Project. Malaysia’s Ministry of Finance issued a sovereign guarantee in support of the loan (PBC). China Eximbank waived the requirement that the borrower purchase buyer’s credit insurance from Sinosure. The borrower made repayments worth $11 million in 2016 and $22 million in 2017. As of December 31, 2017, the loan’s amount outstanding was $297 million. As of December 31, 2018, the loan’s amount outstanding was approximately $288 million (RM 1.2 billion).   The purpose of the project was to construct a 24 km (15 mi) dual carriageway toll bridge that connects Bandar Cassia (Batu Kawan) in Seberang Perai on mainland Peninsular Malaysia with Batu Maung on Penang Island. The bridge consists of precast segmental concrete marine viaducts in 55-meter (180-feet) span modules and a cast in-situ concrete cable-stayed bridge measuring 475 meters (1,558 feet). It is the second bridge to link the island to the mainland after the first Penang Bridge. It extends over 16.9 km (10.5 mi) of water, making it the longest bridge in Malaysia and the second longest in Southeast Asia.   China Harbour Engineering Company Ltd (CHEC) and UEM Builders were the main contractors responsible for implementation. Construction began on November 8, 2008 and the originally scheduled project completion date was November 8, 2013. As of December 2009, the project had achieved an 8.65% completion rate. It was 24% complete as of April 2010. On January 27, 2011, the construction of the main bridge pile foundation was completed. The project was 60.87% complete as of March 2012. The capping of the main tower took place on August 7, 2012. As of October 3, 2012, the project was 84% complete. The final closure of the cable stayed bridge at the main navigational span of the Penang Second Bridge was completed on April 20, 2013. Then, on April 30, 2013, Prime Minister Najib Tun Razak became the country’s first leader to use the Penang Second Bridge to cross from the island to the mainland to attend a function in Kepala Batas, Seberang Perai. Penang Second Bridge was officially completed and accepted by the project owner (JKSB) on September 15, 2013. It was opened to the traffic at 12.01 AM on March 2, 2014 and renamed the Sultan Abdul Halim Muadzam Shah Bridge. It was named after Tuanku Abdul Halim Muadzam Shah, the Sultan of Kedah and the reigning Yang di-Pertuan Agong of Malaysia, by Prime Minister Datuk Seri Najib Tun Razak.
justification: Project is a transportation infrastructure development with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of 24 km dual carriageway toll bridge connecting mainland Peninsular Malaysia with Penang Island, primarily focused on transportation infrastructure

title: China Eximbank provides loan for Rubber Forest Plantation Project (Linked to Project ID#62385 and #70518)
description: In 2005, Sabah State Government granted Bornion Timber Sdn Bhd a 100-year sustainable forest management license for a 100,000 hectare rubber forest. Then, on September 13, 2008, Bornion Timber Sdn Bhd and Guangdong Guangken Rubber Group (also known as 广东省农垦集团公司 or 广东农垦) signed a 50-year, joint venture agreement for the Rubber Forest Plantation Project. The special purpose vehicle that they established is called Bornion Guangken Rubber Sdn Bhd [BGR or 广垦橡胶（沙捞越）有限公司] and it is 50% owned by Bornion Timber and 50% owned by Guangdong Guangken Rubber Group. Then, in late 2009, Guangdong Guangken Rubber Group applied for two loans on behalf of BGR to support the $71.44 million Rubber Forest Plantation Project: a $16.67 million loan from the Guangdong Branch of China Development Bank (CDB) and a loan (with an unknown face value) from the Export-Import Bank of China. In late 2009, the China Eximbank loan was approved. Then, in Q1 of 2010, $1.5 million was disbursed through the China Eximbank loan. Project ID#73574 captures the China Eximbank loan and Project ID#62385 captures the CDB loan (as a pledge). Guangdong Guangken Rubber Group also invested $9.05 million of its own funding to cover 50% of the total project cost (as captured in via Project ID#70518).  The purpose of the project was to construct and operate a 30,000 hectare rubber forest plantation in the Ulu Milan Forest Reserve (Forest Management Unit 11 or FMU11) near the village of Kg Alab Lanas within Keningau District and Sabah State. The project involved the acquisition of agricultural equipment, the planting of rubber trees, and the installation of production facilities and supporting infrastructure. The project was originally expected to be implemented between 2009 and 2021. A formal groundbreaking ceremony took place on July 6, 2009. Then on November 14, 2009, a trial production ceremony was held. BGR recruited more than 1,000 employees to work on the rubber plantation, of which over 90 percent were local hires. However, this project encountered local resistance to implementation. On January 4, 2012, 50 villagers marched into the FMU11 licensed area of Bornion Timber Sdn Bhd (BTSB) and set fire to the workers’ dwellings. The villagers claimed that BTSB had encroached on Native Customary Rights (NCR) land. Then, on January 5, 2012, the villagers lodged a report, accusing BTSB of bulldozing their ancestral burial grounds. They claimed that more than 10,000 acres around the village had been invaded by BTSB, which included rubber plantations, vegetable, rice and other crops. They also claimed that 638 people in the village feared that their native land would be confiscated. BGR reportedly planted more than four million rubber trees in FMU11 between 2009 and 2016. Then, on August 23, 2016, the plantation was officially opened and a rubber tapping ceremony took place.
staff_comments: 1: The Chinese project title is 马来西亚沙巴州1.2万公顷橡胶种植项目 or 来西亚沙巴州1.2万公顷橡胶项目 or 广垦橡胶集团马来西亚沙巴州橡胶种植项目 or 来西亚沙巴州橡胶种植项目.2: The face value of the China Eximbank is unknown. Therefore, AidData has recorded the transaction amount as the value of the Q1 2010 loan disbursement amount ($1.5 million) for the time being.
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
China Eximbank provides loan for Rubber Forest Plantation Project (Linked to Project ID#62385 and #70518)

# Description
In 2005, Sabah State Government granted Bornion Timber Sdn Bhd a 100-year sustainable forest management license for a 100,000 hectare rubber forest. Then, on September 13, 2008, Bornion Timber Sdn Bhd and Guangdong Guangken Rubber Group (also known as 广东省农垦集团公司 or 广东农垦) signed a 50-year, joint venture agreement for the Rubber Forest Plantation Project. The special purpose vehicle that they established is called Bornion Guangken Rubber Sdn Bhd [BGR or 广垦橡胶（沙捞越）有限公司] and it is 50% owned by Bornion Timber and 50% owned by Guangdong Guangken Rubber Group. Then, in late 2009, Guangdong Guangken Rubber Group applied for two loans on behalf of BGR to support the $71.44 million Rubber Forest Plantation Project: a $16.67 million loan from the Guangdong Branch of China Development Bank (CDB) and a loan (with an unknown face value) from the Export-Import Bank of China. In late 2009, the China Eximbank loan was approved. Then, in Q1 of 2010, $1.5 million was disbursed through the China Eximbank loan. Project ID#73574 captures the China Eximbank loan and Project ID#62385 captures the CDB loan (as a pledge). Guangdong Guangken Rubber Group also invested $9.05 million of its own funding to cover 50% of the total project cost (as captured in via Project ID#70518).  The purpose of the project was to construct and operate a 30,000 hectare rubber forest plantation in the Ulu Milan Forest Reserve (Forest Management Unit 11 or FMU11) near the village of Kg Alab Lanas within Keningau District and Sabah State. The project involved the acquisition of agricultural equipment, the planting of rubber trees, and the installation of production facilities and supporting infrastructure. The project was originally expected to be implemented between 2009 and 2021. A formal groundbreaking ceremony took place on July 6, 2009. Then on November 14, 2009, a trial production ceremony was held. BGR recruited more than 1,000 employees to work on the rubber plantation, of which over 90 percent were local hires. However, this project encountered local resistance to implementation. On January 4, 2012, 50 villagers marched into the FMU11 licensed area of Bornion Timber Sdn Bhd (BTSB) and set fire to the workers’ dwellings. The villagers claimed that BTSB had encroached on Native Customary Rights (NCR) land. Then, on January 5, 2012, the villagers lodged a report, accusing BTSB of bulldozing their ancestral burial grounds. They claimed that more than 10,000 acres around the village had been invaded by BTSB, which included rubber plantations, vegetable, rice and other crops. They also claimed that 638 people in the village feared that their native land would be confiscated. BGR reportedly planted more than four million rubber trees in FMU11 between 2009 and 2016. Then, on August 23, 2016, the plantation was officially opened and a rubber tapping ceremony took place.
justification: The project focuses on rubber plantation development, which is primarily an agricultural/industrial activity without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: 30,000 hectare rubber forest plantation, agricultural equipment, rubber tree planting, production facilities

title: China donates 230 million CFA francs of anti-malarial medicine to Mali (linked to #30664 and #30665)
description: On February 12, 2009, Chinese President Hu Jintao and Minister of Commerce Chen Deming signed an agreement to donate a batch of anti-malarial drugs to Mali on behalf of the Chinese government.  The drugs were delivered at a handover ceremony on November 10, 2009.  The Counsellor of the Economic and Commercial Office of the Embassy of Mali, the Director of the General Office of the Ministry of Health of Mali, the Director of Medicine, and the head of the Mali medical team attended the ceremony.  The donation included 230 million CFA francs of antimalarial drugs.   The donation also included equipment and medicines worth 50 million CFA francs to be delivered to Kati Hospital (See Project #30664) and equipment and medicines worth 85 million CFA francs for the use of the Chinese medical mission hospitals in Kati, Sikasso and Markala (See Project #30665).
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
China donates 230 million CFA francs of anti-malarial medicine to Mali (linked to #30664 and #30665)

# Description
On February 12, 2009, Chinese President Hu Jintao and Minister of Commerce Chen Deming signed an agreement to donate a batch of anti-malarial drugs to Mali on behalf of the Chinese government.  The drugs were delivered at a handover ceremony on November 10, 2009.  The Counsellor of the Economic and Commercial Office of the Embassy of Mali, the Director of the General Office of the Ministry of Health of Mali, the Director of Medicine, and the head of the Mali medical team attended the ceremony.  The donation included 230 million CFA francs of antimalarial drugs.   The donation also included equipment and medicines worth 50 million CFA francs to be delivered to Kati Hospital (See Project #30664) and equipment and medicines worth 85 million CFA francs for the use of the Chinese medical mission hospitals in Kati, Sikasso and Markala (See Project #30665).
justification: Project is a healthcare donation with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of anti-malarial drugs and medical equipment, healthcare sector focus
